standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

question.content: The following area model shows $24 \times 32$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each part.**   | | -: | - | :- $A$  | $ = $ |  $B$ | $ = $ |  $C$ | $ = $ |  $D$ | $ = $ |   **What is the total area?**   *Be sure to answer all parts of the question.*  $24 \times 32=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A, has a height of 20 and a base of 30. A second part to the right, labeled B, has the same height as part A and a base of 2. A third part, labeled C, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 4. A fourth part to the right, labeled D, has the same height as part C and a base of 2.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $24 \times 32$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A, and a second part to the right, labeled B, have a curved bracket above them labeled 32. A third part, labeled C, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A. A fourth part to the right, labeled D, has the same base as part B above it. A curved bracket is along the side of parts A and C and is labeled 24.

hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\goldE{A}+\purpleD{B}+\maroonD{C} + \blueE{D}=24\times 32$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its base by its height.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\goldE{A}&=\goldE{30\times 20} \\\\ &=\goldE{600} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{2\times 20}\\\\ &=\purpleD{40} \\\\ \maroonD{C}&=\maroonD{30\times 4}\\\\ &=\maroonD{120} \\\\ \blueE{D}&=\blueE{2\times 4}\\\\ &=\blueE{8} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A equals 30 times 20, has a height of 20 and a base of 30. A second part to the right, labeled B equals 2 times 20, has the same height as part A and a base of 2. A third part, labeled C equals 30 times 4, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 4. A fourth part to the right, labeled D equals 2 times 4, has the same height as part C and a base of 2.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{600}+\purpleD{40} +\maroonD{120}+\blueE{8}=768$  So $24 \times 32 =768$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled 600, has a height of 20 and a base of 30. A second part to the right, labeled 40, has the same height as part A and a base of 2. A third part, labeled 120, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 4. A fourth part to the right, labeled 8, has the same height as part C and a base of 2.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{array}{rcr} A&=&600\\\\ B&=&40\\\\ C&=&120\\\\ D&=&8\\\\ 24\times 32 &= &768 \end{array}$  *Did you include all five parts of the answer?*

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A, has a height of 20 and a base of 70. A second part to the right, labeled B, has the same height as part A and a base of 4. A third part, labeled C, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 6. A fourth part to the right, labeled D, has the same height as part C and a base of 4.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A, and a second part to the right, labeled B, have a curved bracket above them labeled 74. A third part, labeled C, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A. A fourth part to the right, labeled D, has the same base as part B above it. hints.content: To find the area of the whole, we add the area of each part.  $\goldE{A}+\purpleD{B}+\maroonD{C} + \blueE{D}=26\times 74$

To find the area of each part, we multiply its base by its height.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\goldE{A}&=\goldE{70\times 20} \\\\ &=\goldE{1{,}400} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{4\times 20}\\\\ &=\purpleD{80} \\\\ \maroonD{C}&=\maroonD{70\times 6}\\\\ &=\maroonD{420} \\\\ \blueE{D}&=\blueE{4\times 6}\\\\ &=\blueE{24} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled A equals 70 times 20, has a height of 20 and a base of 70. A second part to the right, labeled B equals 4 times 20, has the same height as part A and a base of 4. A third part, labeled C equals 70 times 6, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 6. A fourth part to the right, labeled D equals 4 times 6, has the same height as part C and a base of 4.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{1{,}400}+\purpleD{80} +\maroonD{420}+\blueE{24}=1{,}924$  So $26 \times 74 =1{,}924$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts. The first part, labeled 1,400, has a height of 20 and a base of 70. A second part to the right, labeled 80, has the same height as part A and a base of 4. A third part, labeled 420, is directly below part A and has the same base as part A and a height of 6. A fourth part to the right, labeled 24, has the same height as part C and a base of 4.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{array}{rcr} A&=&1{,}400\\\\ B&=&80\\\\ C&=&420\\\\ D&=&24\\\\ 26\times 74 &= &1{,}924 \end{array}$  *Did you include all five parts of the answer?*
